awd_abstract_narration:
Growth in the fields of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) are critical to the advancement of Missouri State University (MSU), the State of Missouri, and the United States of America.  This Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) project aims to significantly increase the quality and number of graduates in the STEM fields of computer science, engineering, mathematics, and physics at MSU. This will be achieved with the use of scholarships that attract and retain students interested in STEM fields, seminar classes, volunteer opportunities, and tutoring in Calculus II and III and Physics I and II. The core of student support services will be a one credit a semester seminar course. Topics will emphasize other student support opportunities, student success strategies, internships, undergraduate research, employment, and graduate school. Scholarships will be provided to 15 sophomore and 6 transfer students each year based on academic talent and financial need. These scholarships will last two years, provided progression toward graduation. More than 84 computer science, engineering, mathematics, and physics students will be directly impacted by these scholarships.

This project will enhance student retention, performance, breadth of understanding, and student peer support networks as well as enhance the understanding of cohort seminars, course specific tutoring, mentoring, and group building among STEM disciplines on the MSU campus. Each of these areas will be evaluated by an external evaluator associated with this proposed S-STEM project. The evaluation will be conducted using surveys and performance in specific courses to gather both quantitative and qualitative information about all aspects of the project. The results will be used to improve all aspects of the project, many of which will continue beyond the project's duration.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
In 2016, Missouri State University (MSU) received a $630,000 National Science Foundation (NSF) grant to provide scholarships for students in computer science, engineering, math, and physics. The MSU S-STEM program provided two years of financial and academic assistance, supporting students who began their studies at MSU during their sophomore and junior year and supporting transfer students in their first two years at MSU. In addition to scholarships, the MSU S-STEM program provided academic support through requiring participation in a 1-credit hour seminar each fall and through making 12 hours of peer-to-peer academic tutoring available per week.

The seminar had more than 60 presenters from industry and the academy at various stages of their career. Speakers engaged students about college success strategies, internships, transition to the work force, career paths, and graduate education. This also created the opportunity for networking for internships, mentoring, or post-graduation employment.

The seminar was successful in facilitating peer-to-peer connections. This was due to the structure of the seminar itself: (1) having students sit with others in their major (2) requiring that everyone participate in discussion and (3) requiring volunteer hours that could be done collaboratively. 

The seminar was also successful in providing information that facilitated participants’ job search. Through the guest speakers, program participants expanded their understanding of what they could do with their degrees and gained confidence that while finding work is competitive, there is no shortage of STEM jobs. They also learned about the real-world application of their degrees, what to look for in an employer, and got a sense of the local job market.

There were 93 students who received between $1,550 to 2,100 per semester for two years. A total of $521,000 of total funds were dispersed to students.   

The scholarship was meaningful to all evaluation participants. However, the effects were deepest for first generation and non-traditional students. For these participants, receiving the scholarship had multiple positive effects. It was for the first generation and nontraditional students that the synergy between the scholarship and the seminar was clearest. Those who could cut back from full-time employment then had more time to socialize with peers from the seminar outside of seminar, deepening their connections.  

The openness of the scholarships requirements was also particularly important for transfer students and non-traditional students, two groups who tend to have fewer scholarship options than students coming to college straight from high school. It was also useful for a student in the Cooperative Engineering Program, which is run between MSU and a partner campus. He found himself ineligible for other scholarship due to straddling the two institutions.  

The tutoring was the weakest element of the S-STEM program. There were 10 different tutors recruited from computer science and electrical engineering as junior or seniors. Tutoring was for 15 weeks a semester in the fall and spring. A total of 1,280 hours of tutoring were provided at the library to all students on campus, not just participants. Most participants did not use tutoring. Common causes were; incorrect course expertise, group format used at the library, and convenience. Because the tutors were open to all students on campus, tutoring did create a broader impact, but probably at the expense of participants.  

An external evaluation looked at self-efficacy and the broader context in which the program was taking place through interviews and group discussions with 17 of the total 93 participants. Disturbing trends emerged around the intersection of gender and race. Taken together, students face specific challenges in the classroom related to the intersections of race/ethnicity, gender, being first generation or not, and being a traditional student or not.

For many, but not all, of the S-STEM participants who had experienced being minoritized within STEM fields based on gender, race, being first generation, and/or being a nontraditional student, participating the S-STEM program interrupted the cycle. The scholarship placed the same value on all participants. It provided the validation that the student is smart enough to receive this honor, and it provided financial support to bring students closer to parity with students who did not have the same level of financial burden. Bringing the participants together in a well-structured, well facilitated seminar, then reinforced that sense of being smart enough while increasing participants’ cultural capital. For those students who connected with their peers, it expanded their social capital and created friendships that further strengthened confidence and a sense of belonging and became an additional conduit for sharing cultural capital.  

This project had significant and lasting positive impacts on participants, tutors, faculty, MSU students at large, and local employers. This could not have been possible without the generous and necessary scholarship support provided by the NSF.

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2021
Modified by: Matthew C Pierson
